description: Dive into "Verona's Picture-Perfect Moments Await" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Verona's Picture-Perfect Moments Await

places.generalDescription: Piazza delle Erbe, also known as Piazza Erbe, is a storied and historic town plaza located in the north of Verona. Surrounded by cafes and buildings with quaint architecture, it has been a trendy meeting point for locals and tourists alike. The square is bustling with life during the day, hosting a vibrant market where tourists can weave through the stalls. In the evening, it transforms into a souvenir market with bright lights illuminating the area.

sources.snippet: Its fascinating history, spectacular location on the Adige River, and charming Centro Storico, designated a UNESCO World Heritage site, all combine to make it that special destination that you just cannot overlook.
sources.shortName: 26 Amazing Things to Do in Verona, Italy: Stay, Play, and Eat!
Best locations for your photoshoot in Verona

places.name: Piazza delle Erbe

reviews.text:
Iconic & Beautiful Piazza in Verona centre!
This was my favorite place in Verona to have a drink and wonder around, as it has everything, restaurants, cafes, souvenir shops, etc.
If you are lucky you can also catch the market on some days.
I would highly recommend visiting this square, as the building are also beautiful and historical (dating around 15, and 16th century).

üìç Piazza delle Erbe ‚Äì Verona, Italy üáÆüáπ
One of Verona's most vibrant squares üåü, surrounded by historic buildings, frescoed facades üé®, and lively caf√©s ‚òï. Once a Roman forum, today it's full of market stalls üõçÔ∏è selling souvenirs, fruits, and local goods. The square is always bustling üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è with both locals and tourists, giving it a lively atmosphere day and night. A great place to sit with a drink üçπ, people-watch, and soak in the heart of Verona's old town. üôå

Absolutely beautiful piazza unfortunately from my perspective ruined somewhat by the inclusion of multiple "markets" or souvenir shops that spread from one end to the other over certain times. Not sure how often they are open so difficult to comment further.

I believe the markets ruin the atmosphere and ambience of such a grand piazza.
Difficult to even get a decent photo when the markets are open. The markets should be kept to a minimum.

places.generalDescription: The Arena di Verona is a well-preserved Roman amphitheater located near Piazza Bra in the city center. Built in the 1st century AD, it was designed to accommodate up to 20,000 spectators and has retained its original appearance. While not as famous as the Colosseum, it is a stunning piece of architecture with a rich history. In ancient times, it hosted traditional games and shows and later became a venue for events and parties under Scaliger domination.

sources.snippet: Travel Tip // Although Arena di Verona is the clear star of the show, there are lots of Roman treasures and ruins all over the city, above and below ground. Not far from the entry point to the stairs for Castel San Pietro, you‚Äôll find the small 1 BC Teatro Romano (Roman Theatre) by the banks of the Adige. It‚Äôs worth a stop but not essential in our view if your budget or time is tight (in fact, the significant price increase in the last few years to ‚Ç¨9 means that you may only wish to visit if you have the Verona Card, in which case entry is free).
sources.shortName: 13 Wonderful Things To Do in Verona

sources.snippet: One of the largest of its kind and among the best preserved Roman amphitheaters, Verona's arena was built in the reign of Diocletian, about 290 CE. Only four arches of the outer wall on the north side have survived, but the vaulting and seating are intact and in regular use. Its 44 rows of seating can accommodate 22,000 spectators, and in July and August, it is the home of the Verona Opera Festival, one of Europe's major summer music events ranked with the Bayreuth and Salzburg festivals.
sources.shortName: 17 Top-Rated Attractions & Things to Do in Verona

sources.snippet: Of course, the Arena is one of the best  places to go in Verona. It is a stunning historical place, and it attracts the attention of one of the busiest squares in the city, so you are unlikely to miss it. Visiting this ancient Roman amphitheater is one of the best things to do in Verona because it is much more than just a static historical attraction.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Verona

sources.snippet: Not too many travelers can say they attended an event at a 2,000-year-old Roman amphitheater, but visitors to Verona can. This open-air amphitheater, the third largest in Italy, has been a venue for events since the year 30. It was originally built to hold 30,000 spectators at gladiator contests, but now only 15,000 are allowed at events.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to do in Verona, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: Verona welcome you to discover its extraordinary architecture, the well-preserved amphitheater and Verona Arena is an example of them. Verona‚Äôs river Adige meandering through the city is always beckoning you to explore little further into churches, squares and romantic bridges. Find out the best locations for your photoshoot in Verona.
sources.shortName: Best locations for your photoshoot in Verona

sources.snippet: This incredible Roman amphitheater, which was constructed in 30 AD, is known to be one of the BEST preserved arenas in the WORLD!. The Arena is still used for concerts and theatrical productions today, and Aida is showing there in July 2019!. For an up to date schedule of all the upcoming events, check out the schedule here.
sources.shortName: 4 Places to Fall In Love All Over Again in Verona, Italy

sources.snippet: A beautifully preserved Roman amphitheatre which grabs the eye with its symmetry. If you have just an hour to spend in Verona, then make this hour count by dedicating it to Arena di Verona. If you have a whole day in the city of opera and love, then, again, make Arena di Verona the highlight of your exploration of Verona.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy in One Day

sources.snippet: Icon to Verona, we could not but include the Arena in our photographic itinerary. Be creative and take some photos both inside and outside the Arena, in Piazza Br√†. Look for the best angle according to the time of the day.
sources.siteName: Hotel Indigo Verona - Grand Hotel Des Arts
sources.shortName: The 10 most instagrammable places in Verona - Hotel Indigo Verona

sources.snippet: This is one of the best preserved Roman ampitheaters and it is still is use today. You can purchase tickets to tour the inside of the arena or, if your timing is right, see a performance here.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy
10 amazing Instagram spots in Verona

places.name: Arena di Verona

reviews.text:
Since we were in Verona, we had to visit the magnificent Arena. Unfortunately, we couldn't attend an opera performance this time. Still, the place itself is an incredible experience. Sitting on a stone bench that's 2,000 years old and imagining what it was like back then is truly special.

The day was hot, and there's naturally no shade in the outdoor areas of the Arena, so be prepared for high temperatures. Ticket prices are fairly high, especially considering there's not much to see beyond the Arena itself. It's best to buy tickets online-the line at the ticket office is long. We only realized this while waiting in line, but once we bought them online, we got in smoothly.

Seeing an opera here is something you must do at least once in your life!

Nice view from the outside, not very much extra inside. A lot of mechanical/modern machines which takes the charm away. We walked no longer then 20 minutes. A lot of money for this attraction, but feels obligatory when visiting Verona.

One of the most impressive structures to survive from the Roman era! Built in the first century AD, the Arena is a spectacular testament to the architectural power of the Romans. It was once used for spectacular gladiatorial fights, and today it hosts opera performances, concerts and special events. A visit to the Arena is like traveling back in time, an opportunity to experience history up close and marvel at the beauty and grandeur of the ancient structure. You are invited to dive into a world of culture, art and history, and enjoy an unforgettable experience.
The Arena is a huge elliptical structure, designed in pink limestone.
Watch an opera performance: The Verona Arena is known for its spectacular opera performances, which take place in the summer months.
Visit the exhibitions and guided tours, which will tell you about the rich history of the Arena and its various uses over the years.

places.generalDescription: Ponte Pietra is a picturesque Roman arch bridge in Verona, first constructed in 100 BCE and later rebuilt following its destruction in World War II. It's considered one of the city's most romantic symbols. The area around Ponte Pietra offers various attractions such as historical sites like Teatro Romano, Castelvecchio, and ancient churches. Additionally, there are elegant cafes, artisan shops, and high-end boutiques that contribute to the city's charming atmosphere.

sources.snippet: Finished in 100 BCE, it was intended to provide the city with access to the theater on the eastern side of the river.
sources.shortName: A Walk Around Verona Italy In 17 Perfect Instagrams

sources.snippet: Across the Roman bridge of Ponte Pietra, on the hillside below Castel San Pietro, the Roman Theater was built in the first century during the reign of Augustus and excavated between 1904 and 1939. Of the theater itself, you can see the remains of the stage building's tufa walls and stones in the stage pit with holes where the ropes were drawn to open and close the curtains. More remnants are visible of the auditorium, which was built into the hillside in galleries and terraces, including the floor of the orchestra seating with geometric inlaid marble.
sources.shortName: 17 Top-Rated Attractions & Things to Do in Verona

sources.snippet: The Adige River runs through Verona and the most picturesque spot is from Ponte Pietra with the lovely view above to admire. On a sunny day the water glows green against the soft yellow & orange tones of the buildings along the riverside. After snapping your photo, head back across to enjoy a glass of prosecco by the riverside at Terrazza Bar Al Ponte (you can see the canopy in the photo above).
sources.shortName: 10 amazing Instagram spots in Verona

sources.snippet: The Ponte Pietra is the oldest bridge in Verona, built by the Romans in 100 AD. The hun Germans also blew it up when they were retreating WWII, so the white sections are of the only part of the roman arches left before they reconstructed it. They were able to recover a lot of the original Roman material that fell into the river and used that to rebuild the bridge in the 50s.
sources.shortName: YOU GOTTA GO TO VERONA

sources.snippet: This arched stone bridge, the only one in the city, is a famous landmark in Italy and has survived to this day in almost its original form. Changes have been made to the covering of the bridge: the marble that was originally used has been replaced over time by red brick and other materials. This is where the great photos come in.
sources.shortName: Top 25 places to visit in Verona in 2024 (Lots of photos)

sources.snippet: Ponte Pietra (the Stone Bridge) is the only surviving bridge of Roman origins in Verona today. Its elegant arched structure spans the shores of the river Adige leading from the city‚Äôs medieval nucleus to what once was the hotspot of Roman Verona. The first bridge to be erected at that place was made of wood.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy in One Day

sources.snippet: The Ponte Pietra (lit. Stone Bridge) has a very long and troubled history, as it is the only bridge left in Verona that dates back to the Roman era. During the Second World War it was destroyed by the Nazis and later rebuilt by recovering its stones from the Adige.
sources.siteName: Hotel Indigo Verona - Grand Hotel Des Arts
sources.shortName: The 10 most instagrammable places in Verona - Hotel Indigo Verona

sources.snippet: The Ponte Pietra is a multi-arched stone bridge across the Adige River. It is the oldest bridge in Verona, dating back to 100 BC. Cast in shades of burgundy and beige, similar to many other attractions in Verona, the bridge makes for lovely photos from the shore.
sources.shortName: 26 Amazing Things to Do in Verona, Italy: Stay, Play, and Eat!

sources.snippet: Florence has its Ponte Vecchio and Venice, the Rialto Bridge. In Verona, the not-to-be-missed bridge is Ponte Pietra across the Adige River. Built around 100 BC, this bridge is considered one of the most important Roman monuments in Verona.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to do in Verona, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: Then we went on walking down the riverside called Lungadige, crossing the Ponte Pietra, strolling by the lanes near the Duomo and ending up in the Corso Porta Borsari area, where there are some of my favorite perspectives.
sources.shortName: Verona Photographer | Family photo shooting at Giardino Giusti, Verona
Top 5 Places to Take Photos in Verona
12 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy
Best locations for your photoshoot in Verona

places.name: Ponte Pietra

reviews.text: A striking Roman bridge dating back to 100 BC. Spanning the Adige River, it features elegant arches and offers picturesque views of the city and surrounding hills. The bridge beautifully blends history and charm, making it a must-visit landmark for anyone exploring Verona. Its serene atmosphere and architectural beauty provide a perfect backdrop for photos and leisurely strolls.

Strange to review a bridge, it does the job well at getting you from one side of the river to the other without getting wet. It is a pretty little bridge, amazing that parts of the original bridge from 100BC are still there! I thought it would be the paler stones that were the original but it turns out it is the darker, brown bricks, those Romans knew what they were doing alright

In Verona, which is full of beautiful and unique sites, the bridge and the surrounding sights are some of the most special in the city. In the immediate vicinity are good bars and some of the best restaurants in the city.

places.generalDescription: The Castelvecchio Museum in Verona is a restored palace that houses a diverse collection of sculptures, statues, paintings, ancient weapons, and more. Originally built as a residence and fortress in the 14th century, it now offers visitors an immersive experience into medieval life in Verona. The museum features 16 rooms filled with sacred art, Renaissance bronze statues, archaeological finds, coins, weapons, and armor.

sources.snippet: Right next to Ponte Scaligero there‚Äôs a castle turned into a museum ‚Äì Castelvecchio, constructed in 1354. The castle had some unfortunate history after the fall of the Scaligeri family as it was used by the Venetians as a weapons depot and then became barracks during French and Austrian dominion. The restoration of 1926 removed the military elements and inserted late Gothic and Renaissance ones.
sources.shortName: 11 Things to Do in Verona, Italy + Useful Tips from a Local

places.name: Castelvecchio Museum

reviews.text: Looks a little worn around the outside but what a history and it's all there for you to explore. . . very, very reasonable cost and a wealth of exhibits and artwork . . spent far longer here than I imagined . . Staff are friendly and helpful. If you visit Verona, it must be on your list.

Medieval fortress with moat. Probably the best value attraction in Verona, beautifully restored. We spent 3hrs here, exploring the countless corridors and halls. You can also access the battlements and part of the tower. Which has beautiful views of the river and city. There are numerous pieces of veronian artwork including paintings and sculptures. With also a large collection of medieval items of warfare and everyday items. All very interesting with a rich historical significance.

A must on your visit, whether your here for a week or just a few days.
Enjoy!

Very nice museum with an impressive collection of religious art, among other artifacts and weaponry. The entry costs 9 euros and you will have to wait if you go in the morning as there was only one person attending with the tickets' purchase. Do not miss it if you like art and history!

places.generalDescription: Basilica di San Zeno Maggiore is a stunning example of Romanesque architecture located in Verona, Italy. This landmark church, dedicated to Saint Zeno, boasts a rich history and houses an array of religious art. The interior is adorned with airy frescoes and an extraordinary 12th-century bronze door depicting biblical scenes and the saint's miracles. Visitors can also admire Mantegna's vibrant altarpiece, adding to the spiritual and artistic allure of this architectural masterpiece.

sources.snippet: The large 11-12th century Basilica of San Zeno Maggiore is considered the finest Romanesque building in northern Italy. The beautiful main front of alternating strata of brick and white tufa is flanked by a slender Romanesque campanile (1045-1178) and the 14th-century battlemented defensive tower of a former Benedictine abbey. Although you enter through the elegant Romanesque cloister via a gate at the side, be sure to see the bronze doors on the front portal, with outstanding Romanesque reliefs of Biblical and secular scenes.
sources.shortName: 17 Top-Rated Attractions & Things to Do in Verona

sources.snippet: This place is a bit farther than others (actually it's not that far - "farther" in Verona means it's like a 15-minute walk compared to the neighborhood), but it's one of the best places to go in Verona for Romeo and Juliet enthusiasts, as the crypt here is the place where Romeo and Juliet got married in a book. Again, it is an extraordinary place to visit in itself and perhaps one of Verona's most impressive churches (which says a lot, since Verona is undoubtedly not without impressive enough churches to visit).
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Verona

sources.snippet: If you want a full Romeo and Juliet immersion tour, take a detour to Basilica di San Zeo. Its crypt is the location of the wedding in Shakespeare‚Äôs Romeo and Juliet, but it‚Äôs also home to many stunning frescos and bronze doors. This church is also one of the most important examples of Romanesque architecture in Italy and its actual appearance seems to date back to the XII century.
sources.shortName: 11 Things to Do in Verona, Italy + Useful Tips from a Local

sources.snippet: Basilica di San Zeno Maggior isn‚Äôt the biggest or the most important Catholic church in Verona, but it may be the most visited. Its crypt is where, according to Shakespeare, Romeo and Juliet were married. This Romanesque church, the model for later Veronese Romanesque churches, also does well on its own.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to do in Verona, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: Remember when I said that Tim and I had just a few hours in Verona?. With our limited time, we did not get to see everything on this list. This Basilica is one of those places that we missed, but I wanted to include it in this post simply because other visitors to Verona rave about this place.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy

sources.snippet: Saint Zeno‚Äôs Church is a bit of a walk, but if you have the time, it is most definitely worth the effort to get there. The walk is along the river for a part of the way, and through quiet residential streets.
sources.shortName: 26 Amazing Things to Do in Verona, Italy: Stay, Play, and Eat!

sources.snippet: The Basilica is of historical as well as religious interest. Here rest the relics of the city‚Äôs first bishop, St Zeno of Verona. The building was built in Romanesque style and looks quite modest.
sources.shortName: Top 25 places to visit in Verona in 2024 (Lots of photos)
Verona Travel Guide: Top Things to Do & Travel Tips

places.name: Basilica di San Zeno Maggiore

reviews.text:
First of all, I recommend you to buy the ticket "Intero Percorso 4 chiese" with which you can visit the 4 amazing and most important churches of Verona. The price is only 8 Euros per person. All the churches are relatively close to each other so you can visit them on foot.
It was my favourite church in Verona because you can appreciate so many details such as sculptures, paintings, architecture, and the religious history in honour of Saint Zeno.

It's definitely a must visit when in Verona . Adviseable to get  a combo ticket (‚Ç¨8) to see the four sites, including Complessor del Duomo , Sant Anastasia ,  San Fermo . All the sites mentioned are great . Highly recommended !

I recommend getting a 4 church pass, which lets you onto the 4 main churches. The church on the outside doesn't look impressive, but nevertheless.the inside is very impressive. It took us about 20 minutes to walk from our hotel to the church. Unfortunately, you can not go up the tower. All the churches that we visited had lots of history. If you get the chance, go and have a look. I would definitely recommend going and seeing for yourself.

places.address: Piazza San Zeno, 2, 37123 Verona VR, Italy

places.generalDescription: Ponte Scaligero is a historic bridge in Verona, Italy, with a rich past dating back to the 14th century. It features brick and marble construction with three spans and arches. The bridge was reconstructed after being destroyed during World War II, using parts of the original structure. Visitors can enjoy stunning river and city views from the bridge, as well as picturesque photo opportunities along its narrow walkway.

sources.snippet: On the banks of the Adige, Castelvecchio was built by the Scaligeri in 1354-55, an impressive defensive fortress certain to remind any rivals of the power of the della Scala family. Crossing the river is the beautiful castellated Ponte Scaligero, a 14th-century bridge that's traffic free and among the locals' favorite places to go for a stroll. The castle's main tower and ramparts afford views of the bridge, the city, and surrounding hills.
sources.shortName: 17 Top-Rated Attractions & Things to Do in Verona

sources.snippet: Castelvecchio ‚Äì The Old Castle ‚Äì is one of the most precious gems in Verona‚Äôs crown. It is a mighty castle made entirely of red bricks on the shores of the river Adige. Its Gothic crenelated walls and robust square turrets take you right back to the time when the ruthless Scaliger family ruled over Verona.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy in One Day

sources.snippet: Built in the fourteenth century, the bridge unites the banks of the Adige with Castelvecchio. It is made up of three spans and has an original appearance. The surface of the central part is covered with red brick, like the main landmarks of Verona in Scaliger times, the lower part is made of white marble.
sources.shortName: Top 25 places to visit in Verona in 2024 (Lots of photos)

places.name: Scaliger Bridge

reviews.text: A nice bridge with beautiful views of the city. The current bridge was re constructed after WWI. The bridge connects the historic Verona to the more modern one. A very idyllic place.

The Bridge is attached to the Medieval fortress, it has beautiful views of the river and city.

A must on your visit, whether your here for a week or just a few days.
Enjoy!

Picturesque red brick bridge spanning the Adige river.
Was built in 14th century but was destroyed by the retreating German army in 1945 and rebuilt using the same bricks by 1951.

places.generalDescription: Basilica di Santa Anastasia, also known as Chiesa di Santa Anastasia, is a grand 13th-century Gothic church located in the heart of Verona, Italy. This impressive basilica is renowned for its stunning architecture and exquisite artwork, including a remarkable Gothic fresco by Pisanello depicting 'St. George & the Princess.'

sources.snippet: Designed by two Dominican monks, the basilica has a sumptuous Gothic portal. The entrance doors are decorated with bas-reliefs with biblical subjects. Due to unfinished construction work, the upper part of the fa√ßade remains unlined.
sources.shortName: Top 25 places to visit in Verona in 2024 (Lots of photos)

places.name: Basilica di Santa Anastasia

reviews.text:
This is a very beautiful place. Ticket is available for purchase upon entry. There is an  option to choose to enter this particular Basilica for 4eur, and another option for 8eur with entry to multiple Basilicas - which we found is well worth it!!

I would recommend a visit if you are around.

I recommend getting a 4 church pass, which lets you onto the 4 main churches. The church on the outside doesn't look impressive, but nevertheless.the inside is very impressive. If you get the chance, go and have a look. I would definitely recommend going and seeing for yourself.

The Basilica di Santa Anastasia is one of the four historic churches of Verona. The architecture is stunning and the frescoes, sculptures and artwork are just beautiful. The entrance fee is ‚Ç¨4 however if you pay ‚Ç¨8, you can visit all four churches on one ticket. All four churches are worth visiting.

places.generalDescription: Casa di Giulietta, also known as Juliets House, is a 13th-century gothic-style building in Verona that has become a popular tourist attraction. Although it was once owned by the Dal Cappello family and not the Capulets of Shakespeare's story, it still exudes an enchanting charm that captivates visitors.

sources.snippet: Here he is, the winner of the " Instagrammable places of Verona" nomination; Casa di Julietta is Julietta's House (literally translated), where Julietta calls her beloved. I am sure your Instagram subscribers will be happy to see numerous Instagram photos from this beautiful place!. Surprisingly but (especially considering how tragically their story ends), this place is a massive shrine for lovers visiting the city in Italy, who see it as one of the most romantic Instagrammable places to visit.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Verona

sources.snippet: In a country known for romance, romance is what draws most visitors to Casa di Giulietta, the 13th century house where Shakespeare‚Äôs Juliet reportedly was born. There is some speculation as to whether the real-life Juliet lived in the house, though it did once belong to a Cappello family. This doesn‚Äôt deter tourists from flocking to the house where they‚Äôve made the balcony where Shakespeare‚Äôs Romeo pledged undying love to Juliet undoubtedly the most photographed balcony on earth.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to do in Verona, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: Verona is perhaps best known internationally as the setting for Shakespeare's famous tragedy, Romeo and Juliet. Inevitably, tourists asked where the star-crossed lovers lived, and Veronese obligingly pointed out a small medieval palazzo just off Piazza delle Erbe that had an attractive courtyard where tourists could stand without blocking the street. In the 1930s, the city added the missing ingredient, building a balcony overlooking the courtyard.
sources.shortName: 17 Top-Rated Attractions & Things to Do in Verona

sources.snippet: The most iconic spot in Verona has got to be the Case di Giulietta (Juliet‚Äôs House). It‚Äôs free to enter the courtyard and snap a photo of the famous balcony but make sure to come early, as soon as it opens for a crowd free photo. This spot becomes very busy as you can imagine and it‚Äôs a very small space so once the crowds come it can be difficult to take your perfect photo.
sources.shortName: 10 amazing Instagram spots in Verona

sources.snippet: Many people travel to Verona solely in search of Juliet‚Äôs home, and her love blessings, myself included. Casa di Giulietta was on the top of my ‚Äúmust-do‚Äù list for Verona and almost immediately after starting my walk to her home from my Air B&B, I began to fall in love with Verona.
sources.shortName: 17 Photos to Inspire You to Visit Verona, Italy
Verona Travel Guide: Top Things to Do & Travel Tips
Best locations for your photoshoot in Verona

places.name: Casa di Giulietta

reviews.text:
Despite the crowd, visiting Juliet's House was such a special experience. The place radiates a unique charm, filled with romantic history and timeless emotion. Standing beneath the famous balcony felt like stepping into a living fairytale. What truly delighted me was the souvenir shop, absolutely beautiful, filled with lovely, thoughtful items that perfectly capture the spirit of Verona.
A must-visit for every romantic soul. ‚ô•Ô∏è

We stopped by Juliet's House while exploring Verona - it was cool to see the famous balcony and step into the romantic legend for a moment. The museum was closed when we visited, so we only explored the courtyard, which was still worth the visit.

It was very crowded, so don't expect a peaceful experience, but it's an iconic spot and a fun photo opportunity if you're already in the area.

Charming but very crowded! The courtyard with the famous balcony is lovely, but expect lots of people taking photos. Worth seeing for the Shakespearean vibe and romantic atmosphere. Book tickets in advance if you want to go inside the house.

places.generalDescription: Castel San Pietro is a medieval fortress located on a hill overlooking the city of Verona. The fortress, built in 1398, offers stunning panoramic views of the surrounding area. Visitors can reach the castle by taking the Funicolare di Castel San Pietro, a funicular railway that runs up to the hill. While entry into the castle itself is not permitted, many tourists enjoy walking through the beautiful tree-lined streets and capturing picturesque views of Verona from this vantage point.

sources.snippet: Riding Verona‚Äôs Funicular of Castel San Pietro is a lot of fun. In about a minute and a half, its glass cabin takes you vertically 55 metres up on a track that is 159 metres long with an incline of 37%. As you are going up, spellbinding views of Verona open up in front of your eyes.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy in One Day

sources.snippet: The view over Verona from the hill of Castel San Pietro is one of the most photographed, romantic and instagrammable. With its hundred meters height, the hill offers the privilege of a panoramic view over the whole city of Verona. You can reach the hill on foot or by funicular.
sources.siteName: Hotel Indigo Verona - Grand Hotel Des Arts
sources.shortName: The 10 most instagrammable places in Verona - Hotel Indigo Verona

sources.snippet: The bridge is on the easiest walking route from the Piazza Bra or the Piazza delle Erbe to the funicular for Castel San Pietro, so you will find yourself on it if you plan to explore sights on the other side of the Adige.
sources.shortName: 26 Amazing Things to Do in Verona, Italy: Stay, Play, and Eat!

sources.snippet: For a slightly different view of Verona climb up the stairs or take the funicular to Piazzale Castle San Pietro. The way is actually very picturesque ‚Äì I walked my cat there a few times.
sources.shortName: 11 Things to Do in Verona, Italy + Useful Tips from a Local

sources.snippet: From the walls of the historic castle complex, Castel San Pietro, Verona‚Äôs old town lies at your feet. The panorama is simply fantastic.
sources.shortName: Verona Travel Guide: Top Things to Do & Travel Tips
Top 5 Places to Take Photos in Verona
13 Wonderful Things To Do in Verona
Best locations for your photoshoot in Verona

places.name: Castel San Pietro

reviews.text:
The Castel San Pietro is a historic fortress located near the historic centre of Verona. the hill: Colle San Pietro was first developed as a military fort in the 12th and 13th centuries with a current buildings on-site dating back to the mid nineteenth century, constructed during Austrian rule.

There was a lovely hike to the summit of Castel San Pietro, offering panoramic views down to the river and across all of Verona. I can certainly recommend a visit.

Fantastic spot to get a full view of the City of Verona. Stunning views. Small funicular railway takes you to the top where you can get lovely coffees, deserts and ice creams on a hot day. The peace and quiet up here is just what you need after leaving the city streets.

I highly recommend coming here just for the views. There was a musician playing the guitar by the name of Claudio Romano, and he played Corcovado so nicely that I bought his CD for 10 euro (see videos for sound). I parked here, and took an automated tram that allowed us to not have to hike up in hot weather.

places.address: Piazzale Castel S. Pietro, 2, 37129 Verona VR, Italy

places.generalDescription: Piazza dei Signori, also known as Dante's Square, is a historic public square located in the north of Verona's city center. Surrounded by notable buildings and connected by arcades, it holds great significance as the political center of the city. The square features a prominent statue of Dante Alighieri and several cafes. Once crucial for Verona's governance, it now stands as an intricately organized and lovely square with historical importance.

sources.snippet: Right next to Piazza della Erba is Piazza dei Signori, often overlooked by tourists. While on a daily basis it‚Äôs often used for Christmas, Easter and Valentine‚Äôs markets, it‚Äôs historically very important spot. To start with, it‚Äôs often called Piazza Dante because of a monument of Dante Alighieri, the author of The Divine Comedy.
sources.shortName: 11 Things to Do in Verona, Italy + Useful Tips from a Local

places.name: Piazza dei Signori

reviews.text: Piazza dei Signori is a historic square in Verona that exudes charm and elegance. Surrounded by stunning architecture, including the impressive Palazzo del Podest√† and the statue of Dante Alighieri, the square serves as a cultural hub. Its vibrant atmosphere is enhanced by cafes and shops, making it an ideal spot for relaxation and people-watching. Whether you're admiring the beautiful buildings or enjoying a coffee, Piazza dei Signori is a delightful highlight of any visit to Verona.
Nice Piazza to roam around and taste their local food.
This was such a beautiful Piazza! Really loved looking at all the buildings and the art work.

places.address: P.za dei Signori, 37121 Verona VR, Italy

places.generalDescription: In the heart of Verona's Old City, stands the impressive Torre dei Lamberti, a medieval tower built in 1172 by the influential Lamberti family. Rising to a height of 84 meters, it offers commanding views of the ancient city and its red-tiled rooftops. Visitors can climb this historic landmark for panoramic vistas over Verona.

sources.snippet: Walk beneath the mysterious Arco della Costa (see the last bullet point under point 5 above) and just a few steps further down the passageway, you will find the entrance to another of Verona‚Äôs main sights. Torre dei Lamberti is a 84 metres tall tower the construction of which was ordered by the noble Lamberti family back in the distant year of 1172. Buy a ticket and scale the tower‚Äôs 368 steps or ‚Äì better ‚Äì take the fast and convenient lift and soon you will be enjoying stunning views over Verona.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy in One Day

sources.snippet: Rising above the Piazza Delle Erbe, this tower is one of the Instagrammable places for your project " best places in Verona," where you can enjoy incredible views of Verona (after all, no wonder, because it is a tower). It occupies such a brilliant position overlooking the town and is a great place to visit to get a proper idea of how vast (and how relatively flat) the city is. Now you can either climb the numerous stairs leading to the tower or take the elevator directly upstairs.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Verona

sources.snippet: Constructed in 1172 and heightened to its current lofty 84 meters (276 feet) in the 1400s, Torre dei Lamberti dominates the skylines of both Piazza delle Erbe and Piazza dei Signori. You can distinguish the two periods of construction, as the old tower was built in layers of tuffa and terra cotta, giving it a striped appearance. You can climb the 368 steps spiraling to the top to see the stonework up close, or you can take the glass elevator for a faster view of the interior.
sources.shortName: 17 Top-Rated Attractions & Things to Do in Verona

sources.snippet: The card is available in two versions: Either for 24 hours (20 euros) or for 48 hours (25 euros, each valid from the first use. With the card you get free entry into almost all the main attractions including the Arena, the Torre dei Lamberti or the Castelvecchio. At the Arena the card is twice as worthwhile because it gives you preferential admission and often you can skip the long waiting line at the ticket counter.
sources.shortName: Verona Travel Guide: Top Things to Do & Travel Tips

sources.snippet: When I first climbed Torre dei Lamberti I loved the view, but unfortunately, since my first and second visits things have changed and now there‚Äôs a net (I assume people were throwing things down). It‚Äôs still fun to go up if you have the time. The tower is 83 meters high, and in 1464, an octagonal floor was added.
sources.shortName: 11 Things to Do in Verona, Italy + Useful Tips from a Local

sources.snippet: The Torre dei Lamberti stands out 84m high above the skyline of Verona as the tallest building in the city. Before you head up the tower (see 3) make sure to pose on the beautiful steps that lead up to the entrance (once you have your ticket). The rich terracotta and peach brickwork make a fantastic backdrop.
sources.shortName: 10 amazing Instagram spots in Verona

sources.snippet: Gaze up at the beautiful Torre dei Lamberti, which rises up from one end of the square. Admire the beautiful frescoes on the facades. Walk over to view the 14th century fountain, topped by a much more ancient Madonna statue from the 4th century.
sources.shortName: 26 Amazing Things to Do in Verona, Italy: Stay, Play, and Eat!

sources.snippet: For one of the best views of the city, visit Torre dei Lamberti. The quickest way to the top is via the elevator, but if you want to eat more gelato, take the steps to the top.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy
13 Wonderful Things To Do in Verona
Best locations for your photoshoot in Verona

places.name: Torre dei Lamberti

reviews.text: Super tower,  not very expensive to go up. There are two ways up. You can use the lift, which takes a couple of minutes to get to the top or the stairs. There are about 400 steps up. But it's definitely worth the climb up. The views are amazing.  Definitely recommend it to anyone who wants to go up.

The Torre dei Lamberti is a 84 m high tower giving the best 360¬∞ views over the city. There is a lift which takes you up most of the way or you can do stairs(368). Due to the final climb, there is no wheelchair access.
Would suggest you book ahead to avoid the queues. Be aware bells ring every half hour!!
Take note, the whole observation deck has netting & wire mesh!

Amazing...the most impressive view of the beauty of the beautiful city of Verona. The place is wonderfully organized. Don't miss a visit to the local museum up the stairs to the palace at the base of the tower.

places.address: Via della Costa, 1, 37121 Verona VR, Italy

places.generalDescription: Arco dei Gavi is a massive ancient white-marble arch that was originally constructed during the first century AD as part of the city defenses and served as a major gate into what is now the historic city center. It was dismantled by the French and later reassembled in 1932. The town of Arco, where it is located, has a Tyrolean feel with a ruined castle, beautiful churches, and palaces.

sources.snippet: You will find it right next to the medieval Castelvecchio (see point 20 below) with the river Adige flowing fast behind it. The Gavi‚Äôs Arch was built in the 1st century AD in honour ot the gens Gavia ‚Äì a noble Roman family of plebeian descent. Adorned with statues (since then lost) of members of the Gavi family, the arch was originally placed on Via Postumia.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy in One Day

sources.snippet: After a while, you strolling alleys around the Arena and your next stop will be the Arco dei Gavi. A Roman gate which can be used as a beautiful background. At  the end the Castle Vecchio situated on what was probably once a Roman fortress site just outside of the city walls, will be waiting for you.
sources.shortName: Best locations for your photoshoot in Verona

sources.snippet: Right next door to Castelvecchio is the Arc de Gavi, an ancient arch built by the noble family Gavia, which was once the gateway to the city. The arch was not really near Castelvecchio, and was moved there in later years (much, much later) and is quite impressive right by the river.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Verona

sources.snippet: This Roman gate was constructed in the 1st century over the Roman road leading into Verona. It stood for centuries until French engineers destroyed it during Napoleonic rule. It was reassemble in 1932.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy

sources.snippet: You‚Äôll find the beautiful Arco dei Gavi by the river, near Castelvecchio. It‚Äôs a photogenic structure, but it also has a fascinating (and long) history.
sources.shortName: 26 Amazing Things to Do in Verona, Italy: Stay, Play, and Eat!

places.name: Arco dei Gavi

reviews.text: Romantic place for lovers. River, old castle, green garden, ducks, bridges.... and just imagine to hug some sweet girl...

The Arco dei Gavi is a roman gateway set in a small park overlooked by Castlevecchio, with seats and a view of the river and bridges. The arch had been dismantled by Napoleon to send to France, however it was eventually reassembled in 1932 as all the sections had been numbered originally by the romans. The original position of the arch is marked by marble stone slabs in the roadway outside Castelvecchio and a marble plaque details this on the castle wall.

A Roman gateway impressive enough for Napoleon to dismantle ready for shipment back to France. Its original position is marked by marble stone slabs in the roadway outside Castelvecchio and a marble plaque on the wall. Not reassembled until 1932 it now sits alongside Castelvecchio in a small square. Open access 24 hours.

places.generalDescription: Complesso del Duomo di Verona, also known as the Complex of the Dumo, is a collection of ancient Christian buildings in Verona. The main attraction is the Cattedrale di Santa Maria Matricolare, a stunning example of Romanesque architecture with Gothic influences. The cathedral houses an impressive Assumption of the Virgin painting by Titian and features a lavish interior adorned with frescoes.

sources.snippet: The cathedral is a 12th-century Romanesque basilica with a 15th-century Gothic nave. Adjoining it is a campanile on a Romanesque base, designed by Sanmicheli but not completed until 1927. On the beautiful main doorway of the cathedral are figures of Charlemagne's two paladins, Roland and Oliver, done between 1139 and 1153.
sources.shortName: 17 Top-Rated Attractions & Things to Do in Verona

places.name: Cattedrale di Santa Maria Matricolare

reviews.text: The Duomo di Verona (Cattedrale di Santa Maria Assunta) is a must-see if you're exploring the city's historic center. Built on the site of early Christian churches, it was reconstructed in the Romanesque style after a major earthquake in 1117. The interior is stunning, featuring red Verona marble columns, Gothic arches, and several chapels with Renaissance frescoes. One highlight is the Assumption of the Virgin by Titian, located in the Cartolari-Nichesola Chapel. The cathedral is part of a larger complex that includes the Baptistery of San Giovanni in Fonte and the Church of Sant'Elena, where you can see ancient mosaic floors. There wasno entry fee and we got an opportunity to hear the organ, although it was only being tuned.

Florence is a charming and peaceful town, a complete contrast to the bustling crowds of Rome. Strolling along its ancient cobblestone streets, one can feel the gentle rhythm of life, steeped in art and history. At its heart stands the Duomo Cathedral ‚Äì with its iconic orange-red dome, like the beating heart of the city. It may not be massive, but it exudes grace and irresistible charm.

Unusually for Italy, Verona's duomo is hidden away down narrow  streets and enclosed by surrounding buildings. Only the tall bell tower standing over the rooftops gives away its location from any distance.
Perhaps because of this the exterior is not particularly striking. Step inside though and there are wonders galore. The fabulously ornate gilded organ casing has hinged door panels that are painted with allegorical scenes on the inside face so that they can only be seen when open.
The cathedral walls have stunning frescoes with clever perspective to appear like marble panelling. And the fresco in the dome is alive with saintly figures in supplication to the virgin Mary.
There is plenty of space and seats to sit and appreciate the artistry and craftsmanship.

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Verona, the Scaliger Tombs stand as a magnificent tribute to the powerful Scaligeri family, who ruled this enchanting city during the 13th and 14th centuries. These Gothic funerary monuments are not just tombs; they are intricate works of art that reflect the family's noble heritage and influence over medieval Verona.

sources.snippet: The Scaliger family ruled Verona in the 13th and 14th centuries. A set of five beautiful Gothic tombs, celebrating five prominent members of this ruling family, can be viewed in Verona‚Äôs historic center.
sources.shortName: 26 Amazing Things to Do in Verona, Italy: Stay, Play, and Eat!
Best locations for your photoshoot in Verona

places.name: Scaliger Tombs

reviews.text: The Scaliger Tombs (Arche Scaligere) in Verona are a remarkable example of Gothic funerary architecture. These ornate tombs, dedicated to the Scaligere family, showcase intricate carvings and towering structures that reflect the wealth and influence of this historical dynasty. Located near the picturesque Piazza dei Signori, the tombs are not only a testament to Verona's rich history but also a captivating sight for visitors. The serene atmosphere and detailed artistry make it a must-visit for anyone exploring the city's cultural heritage.

The Scaliger Tombs in Verona are a striking example of Gothic funerary art, situated beside the small church of Santa Maria Antica. These elaborate monuments were built for the powerful della Scala family, who ruled Verona during the 13th and 14th centuries. Each tomb features detailed stone carvings and is topped with a statue of the deceased on horseback, highlighting their status and legacy. Despite their grandeur, the tombs are slightly tucked away behind a decorative iron gate, giving them a mysterious and almost hidden presence in the city's historic center.

Really interesting and beautiful tombs. A very small site, but well worth seeing, and you get free entry with a Verona Card. The staff were really lovely and helpful as well, and gave us lots of information. Worth a trip

places.address: Via S. Maria Antica, 4, 37121 Verona VR, Italy

places.generalDescription: Porta Borsari is an ancient limestone gate dating back to the 1st century, serving as the main entrance to the city of Verona. The area surrounding it is rich in history, with medieval and Renaissance palazzos waiting to be explored. Visitors can also experience the romantic ambiance of Juliet's House and its beautiful Renaissance frescoes.

sources.snippet: Corso in Italian means ‚Äòmain street‚Äô in English and here are two of the main streets in Verona which follow a straight line and merge one into another. Corso Sant‚ÄôAnastasia starts from the homonymous church (see point 17 above) and then, at Piazza delle Erbe (see point 5 above), this long straight street becomes Corso Porta Borsari which takes you all the way to the Roman Borsari Gate. It‚Äôs interesting to note that Corso Sant‚ÄôAnastasia and Corso Porta Borsari follow the exact line of the ancient Decumanus Maximums ‚Äì Verona‚Äôs main road in Roman times.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Verona, Italy in One Day

sources.snippet: In the days of the ancient Romans, Porta Borsari was the gate through which travelers entered the city of Verona. It also was the point where these travelers paid a tax to enter and leave the city. Since it was the city‚Äôs main entrance on Via Postumia, it was ornately decorated with columns and arched windows.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Things to do in Verona, Italy (+Map)

sources.snippet: The Porta Borsari gate is another evidence of Verona‚Äôs need for protection. They were built in the 1st century and were part of the defensive wall. Since it was used as a main entrance, the gate was richly decorated, and the whole construction with it looked rather impressive.
sources.shortName: Top 25 places to visit in Verona in 2024 (Lots of photos)

sources.snippet: If you enjoy shopping, stroll the Corso Porta Borsari: it has several nice shoe shops!. Or Via Mazzini, which leads out of Piazza Bra, and features many brand name stores.
sources.shortName: 26 Amazing Things to Do in Verona, Italy: Stay, Play, and Eat!

places.name: Porta Borsari

reviews.text: What a great ancient gate dates to the first century , the amazing thing the gate still in a good condition üìúüòç
A beautiful wonder of the city. A feeling of reverberation in the heart to walk through it!

The second of the two Roman gateways to the old city still has both of its arches in tact  and the road through it leads to the original Roman Forum (Piazza Erbe). Unfortunately it has been covered over for repairs. View from pavement, no access charges open 24 hours.

places.address: Corso Porta Borsari, 57A, 37121 Verona VR, Italy
